user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_:
```c
bool
MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   bool nodelay_state)
{
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
  int err_code;

  if (_MHD_YES == connection->is_nonip)
    return false;

  if (0 == setsockopt (connection->socket_fd,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) (nodelay_state ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (off_val)))
  {
    connection->sk_nodelay = nodelay_state;
    return true;
  }

  err_code = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
  if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_))
  {
    if (_MHD_UNKNOWN == connection->is_nonip)
      connection->is_nonip = _MHD_YES;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed "
                   "for TCP/IP socket %d: %s\n"),
                "TCP_NODELAY",
                nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
                (int) connection->socket_fd,
                MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
    }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed: %s\n"),
              "TCP_NODELAY",
              nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
              MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */

#else  /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  (void) connection; (void) nodelay_state; /* Mute compiler warnings */
#endif /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_ function and found no use of the Standard Library function memcmp. There are no manual byte-wise comparisons of C strings, no calls to memcmp, and no apparent comparisons of null-terminated strings using memory functions. The code only uses integer comparisons, pointer/boolean checks, setsockopt, and logging with string literals. Macros and functions used here (e.g. MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_, MHD_socket_strerr_, MHD_DLOG) are invoked but their definitions are not in this fragment; nothing in this function text calls memcmp or performs a memcmp-style comparison of null-terminated strings, so there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
